m_DescList: As regular expressions grow increasingly complex, a single text match may capture multiple groups.
We assign unique names to these expressions to distinguish which captured group result we should retrieve.

We can name the expected capturing group for <color=#AB2800>A</color> as <color=#AB2800>test</color>, constructing the expression: <color=#05C3BA>(?</color><color=#AB2800><test>A</color><color=#05C3BA>)</color>
<color=#3c3cff><test>A</color>  The match result of the "test" capturing group

For example, to match the integer before the decimal point in text and name this capturing group as "int", construct: <color=#05C3BA>(?</color><color=#AB2800><int></color><color=#3173FF>\d</color><color=#FF68DD>+</color><color=#05C3BA>)</color><color=#AB2800>\.</color><color=#3173FF>\d</color><color=#FF68DD>+</color>
<color=#3c3cff><int>1</color> The match result of the "int" capturing group
Corporate emails require matching names within email text. The content to match has the following characteristics:
2. Follows patterns: name is xxx, name: xxx, name:xxx
3. Names exclude symbols \n , . â€“ stop matching when encountering these
Please construct a regular expression that passes all tests on the right.
